facts.text: Order of detention passed by District Magistrate, Jodhpur on March 18, 1974 under s.3(1)(a)(iii) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

Petitioner taken into custody on March 19, 1974; first detention order served on arrest stating indulgence in rampant adulteration of essential foodstuffs via factory/firm Laxmi Narain Moondra, Makrana Mohalla, Jodhpur.

Recovery from godown and flour mill: 170 bags including 7 tins sawdust, 15 bags flour yellow and Gherwa, 70 bags chilli seed, black flour leaves like tea leaves, 1 bag gypsum khaddi powder, 1 tin animal dung, used/intended for adulteration; also Haldi, Mirchi, Amchoor found adulterated on chemical exam, prosecution contemplated under Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954.
Second order with further particulars served on March 20, 1974 detailing raid info from Shri Hiranand on 11-3-1974.
Raid 11-3-1974, 11:30am-2pm by Dr. Miss Raj Kumari et al. at Sumer Market, info from Hiranand confirmed adulteration business; petitioner and son present.

11-3-1974 main shop: 11 full +7 half bags adulterated chilli powder (80kg-20kg), 1 quintal Haldi powder +2 half bags, 10-20kg Amchur bags, 1 tin Dhaniya mixed refuse, 2 tins Tumba oil; samples taken, price paid, forms IV/V given, sealed.
11-3-1974 two rooms main shop sealed: 60 bags chilli powder, 10 Haldi, 5 Amchur, 5 unhusked Amchur.

11-3-1974 main shop adulteration materials: 1 bag gypsum Khaddi, half bag red flour for chilli, I.C.I. flour green for Dhaniya, saffron flour for Haldi, red coloured plastic paper, weights/weighing machines.
12-3-1974 godown No.1&2: 62 bags chilli unhusked seeds.
13-3-1974 godown: 34 bags chilli seeds, 10 tins black tea-leaves-like, 99 tins white powder, 2 bags soap stone powder.

13-3-1974 & 14-3-1974 flour mill (license 1666 in wife Ramadevi's name): 11 bags husked chilli seeds, 2 tins donkey dung, 11 tins sawdust, 1 tin yellow sawdust, 1 tin mango seed powder, 2 tins Dhaniya waste.
Samples by Public Analyst: Chilli powder - total ash 8.12%, ash insoluble HCl 1.99% silicious sand etc.; Haldi 46.24% insects; Amchur 20% extraneous matter.

Statements of Hiranand and landlord Ramesh Chandra Mathur: long-time business; failed to produce firm registration; refused to open flour mill (opened via s.10 PFA Act); fraudulent writings on cardboard.
State Govt approved detention March 23, 1974.
Petitioner moved Rajasthan High Court under Art.226 ~April 6, 1974; dismissed May 6, 1974.
Reference to Advisory Board April 10, 1974.
Detenu representation dated 16/17 April 1974, despatched April 17, received Govt April 20; considered by Advisory Board, heard in person, reported sufficient cause.
Detention confirmed May 11, 1974.
DM affidavit in High Court: knew of previous prosecution under PFA Act but judgment not available, so unsure of conviction.
Petitioner previously convicted once under PFA Act on confession advice to avoid trial.

legal_issues.text: Whether grounds of detention are non-existent.
Whether grounds communicated are not germane having direct nexus with maintenance of supplies and services essential to community.
Whether failure to mention previous conviction in grounds, despite DM's knowledge of prosecution, made grounds vague and violated Art.22(5)/s.8(1) MISA.

petitioner_arguments.text: Donkey dung, sawdust, gypsum, ICI colours etc. not adulterants but for innocuous purposes (fuel, ice preservation); no evidence of use in adulteration; none of foodstuffs mixed with them; only sub-standard samples with minor sand/insects due to nature, no nexus.
Food adulteration not prejudicial to maintenance of supplies/services essential to community.
DM knew of previous prosecution/conviction but not mentioned in grounds, depriving explanation opportunity; grounds vague.

respondent_arguments.text: Public Analyst reports indicate possibility of dung, sawdust, gypsum in samples (silicious matter, dust-stones as gypsum, fibre/ash); seizure of adulterants with adulterated foodstuffs relevant to maintenance of supplies.
DM did not know of conviction (only prosecution, judgment unavailable); not required to communicate as substance in raids/adulterants; facts known to detenu.

court_reasoning.text: Presence of donkey-dung, sawdust etc. in premises with adulterated foodstuffs suspicious; no license for them; doubt on innocuous uses; Analyst did not exclude them (gypsum possible in insoluble ash/dust-stones); samples prima facie adulterated u/s.2(i)(b,c,f) PFA Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suspicion strengthened by bulk storage and adulterated samples; grounds not non-existent.

court_reasoning.text: Food adulteration, esp. organized/large-scale, prejudicial to maintenance of supplies/services essential to community as supplies mean wholesome foodstuffs, not adulterated; distinguishes Misri Lal (too narrow), approves Hari Ram; food as supply/service.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Adulteration disrupts even flow of essential supplies/services.

court_reasoning.text: DM knew prosecution not conviction; grounds incorporate raids/adulterants as substance; previous details not essential, known to detenu, explained to Advisory Board.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No contravention of Art.22(5)/s.8(1); objection afterthought.

court_reasoning.text: Preventive detention precautionary, not punitive; test: reasonable prognosis of future activity based on past/present magnitude/impact; here satisfied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Caution: only for habitual/large-scale, not petty.

holdings.text: Organized/large-scale food adulteration prejudicial to maintenance of supplies/services u/s.3(1)(a)(iii) MISA warranting preventive detention if reasonable prognosis of continuance.
Grounds of detention exist and germane; no violation in non-communication of previous conviction details.
Samples prima facie adulterated u/s.2(i)(b,c,f) PFA Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Narrow view that food adulteration not prejudicial to supplies rejected.
Adulteration of essential commodity prejudicial to its supply.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar
Haradhan Saha v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction preventive vs punitive detention; prognosis test.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order; communication of grounds; Advisory Board reference.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of adulterated food; samples/search; contemplated prosecution.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition; habeas corpus; right to know grounds.

outcome.summary: Writ petition under Art.32 challenging detention order dismissed; all contentions rejected; rule discharged.

key_quotes.text: "Supplies in the context of s.3(1)(a)(iii) means the supply of essential commodities or foodstuffs in a wholesome form. It does not mean the supply of their adulterated substitute."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on nexus of adulteration to maintenance of supplies.

key_quotes.text: "The power of preventive detention is a precautionary power exercised in reasonable anticipation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes preventive from punitive; sets prognosis test.

key_quotes.text: "Only big whales plunging to prey unleash tidal waves which disturb the even keel of communal life, the little fry acting in a small way... matter little."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Caution on use of detention power for large-scale only.
